To enforce RBAC on resources accessed by SimCorp Dimension (SCD), multiple implementations are offered to cater to different deployment scenarios.   There are multiple options how we can configure the connection – (a) SimCorp creates secret in Single Tenant App Registration, or (b) SimCorp receives a certificate from Client and adds it in Single Tenant App Registration 
SimCorp add the Enterprise App connected to the Single Tenant App Registration (aka Service Principal) to the relevant groups to grant proper role to proper entities 
SCD services instantiate the connection using TenantID (SimCorpCloud Tenant ID), AppID (the Single Tenant App Registration ID) and either Secret (a) or Certificate (b) 
Azure Clients:   
Clients using Azure can register a multi-tenant app in their Azure subscription. They will share the AppId with us, and we will register it as a service principal.

For security reasons it is now possible to specify SCD user ID for the configuration parameter CfgSvcGrantAllTasks.
Syntax:
CfgSvcGrantAllTasks=Enabled [;SCDID]
Enabled: 0 or 1

To be backward compatible the old syntax is still valid.

Examples:
CfgSvcGrantAllTasks=1 (the option is enabled)
CfgSvcGrantAllTasks=1;SCDID1 (the option is enabled if the current SCD user is SCDID1, for all other users it will be disabled).

Synthetic FX Hedge Return Calculation Settings currently supports four price methods that place the entire market value of the FX forward contract on one leg. It will therefore be the single leg that holds the entire P/L and return of the contract. There is, however, a conceptual problem with these methods, since the start of day market value on the value bearing leg is also zero. TWR is therefore not well defined on the opening date when using these price methods. The existing calculation applies a trick where the return is calculated on each leg and then simply subtracted from each other and put to the value bearing leg. One way to understand this approach is that it calculates a unitized P/L for each leg and moves these to the single leg. This approach is, however, difficult to understand and explain. On top of this, when the synthetic FX hedge returns are used in Investment Analytics Platform - Performance, they are always used on a synthetic FX forward that has two non-zero legs. This might not be the expected behavior if SCD is setup to calculate the returns using a price method that implicitly treats the FX forward as a single-legged instrument. Since these methods are not recommended from a performance perspective, they are removed as calculation options from the Synthetic FX Hedge Return Calculation Settings window. Instead, the four corresponding P/L price methods are added. These are recommended from a performance perspective since they have market value on both legs.
